text: We'll hear argument next in Number 97-1418, Bank of America National Trust and Savings v. 203 North LaSalle Street.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
May I ask just a... I'm a little fuzzy on the facts.
It's the same partnership.
It's reconstituted with the... some partners contributed and some did not; is that right?
That's correct, Your Honor.
So that it's actually a different group of individuals than it was before?
It is a--
If it's a different partnership, in effect, do they have different partners?
--It is the reorganized debtor.
Are there any individuals in the new partnership that were not in the former one?
I don't know the answer to that question, Your Honor.
Well, the new partnership still preserved the tax shelter, right?
That's correct, Your Honor.
What if the plan here had let any creditor participate if it wanted to--
That would be a very different case, Your Honor.
--in the reorganization?
That would be a very different case.
Would that have satisfied the claim here and overcome the so-called absolute priority rule?
It might well have.
And what section is that, Mr. Englert?
It's section 1129(b)(2)(B)(ii) of the Bankruptcy Code.
Could I ask you a quick preliminary question just to test my knowledge.
The claim of our client... of my client?
--Yeah.
The creditor is owed 93 million dollars.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.
